ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learned about collaboration, mentorship, grant writing, and how to give a pitch.
I learned about different industries that people can go into with a BME degree, how to write abstracts of grants and how to make a pitch deck
I learned about future careers in Biomedical Engineering and beyond!
I got the chance to think about three different career path options that were presented to us: academia, academic medicine, and startup/biotech/industry. We reflected on our values as well.
This course was a great overview of different post-grad options for Biomedical Engineers. We got to hear from a very wide variety of speakers and discussions were engaging.
I developed a more in-depth understanding of the various job opportunities available to me after graduation.
Really great, we got to learn more about biomedical engineering in the workplace and as a carreer, and learned more skills to help us in the future

This class allowed me to truly reflect on who I am and how that translates to my professional career. It helped me affirm my interests and discover a new way of thinking about things that strengthen me, which I will be applying for many years to come.

The opportunity to explore real-life applications and careers in the field of Biomedical Engineering. Met pioneers in the academic and industry areas for biotechnology, pharmaceutical companies, and medicine.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths of the course was the diverse array of speakers that were invited to talk.
Strengths: Prof. Tietjen and Archie are wonderful and clearly care about their students. The speakers we heard from were also super interesting!

I liked the chance to reflect on my values and goals in a low-stress environment. The writing assignment was fun.

It could have a broader range of speakers from different industries. We could represent more types of folks outside of just these main areas.

The range of speakers was excellent. I liked the focus on connecting your next career steps with what qualities strengthen you. Although there were fewer virtual classes, when it was over zoom I found it difficult to stay engaged. It would be helpful in the future to keep all classes in person, even if that means the speaker is on zoom but the students are watching together in the classroom. Also, the idea of a final pitch presentation was nice and low stress, but I think it would have been fun to do it in person.

Strengths of this course include the low stress approach, personal stories of successful speakers, and opportunities for attempting a project. I honestly cant really think of many weaknesses. This class did what it aimed to do, and Professor Tietjen taught it well.
Really great course!!! Alot of self reflection, and you get to see lots of perspectives
I loved having all the speakers and the relaxed nature of the course. I would say that the low-stakes environment was much appreciated by many.

Many of the assignments were less structured than I would like. In addition, notifications about lecturers, assignments, and events often came the day of with little notice. The strengths was definitely the exposure and the people we were able to meet and talk to. Many doctors, CEOs, CFOs, and CMOs, a range of all titles and positions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It's open to non-BME majors and a good way to explore topics in science / hear cool people talk.
Well it's required for BME students but it was pretty good as a seminar and career strategies.

Yes, it's a low-workload, high emotional/intellectual-reward course that promotes earnest self-reflection and collaboration. It was also really fun to take a class with the other students in my BME cohort :)
Yes! It's worthwhile if you engage with it especially!
If youre majoring it BME, working in a BME-related field, or wanting to learn about entrepreneurship, then Id recommend this course. Otherwise, not really.
I would! If you are a BME major, and want to know more about biomedical engineering beyond college
This is catered towards BME students, but it also provides different perspectives in professional development for any STEM student.
Yes! Definitely an amazing class to see if anything strikes your fancy. Great opportunities to connect with speakers and maybe even try to get a job or some shadowing experience!
